snippet.textDisplay: The only thing I can hear when this is playing is the 'wheop' sound of a healing spell being used.
snippet.textOriginal: The only thing I can hear when this is playing is the 'wheop' sound of a healing spell being used.

snippet.textDisplay: The only thing and I mean the only thing I didn't particularly like about this game was the walking speed in the overworld and towers/dungeons/caves. They at least could've sold you some Sprint Shoes or something to make you walk faster. I know there are hacks that make it to where you can, but to me not fooling around with something in some cases is better, but this is not one of those cases.
snippet.textOriginal: The only thing and I mean the only thing I didn't particularly like about this game was the walking speed in the overworld and towers/dungeons/caves. They at least could've sold you some Sprint Shoes or something to make you walk faster. I know there are hacks that make it to where you can, but to me not fooling around with something in some cases is better, but this is not one of those cases.

snippet.textDisplay: Can you enter this cave through another entrance so you can supervise our work on the bridge from that ledge over there?
snippet.textOriginal: Can you enter this cave through another entrance so you can supervise our work on the bridge from that ledge over there?

snippet.textDisplay:
My main complaint is that game's plot just moves WAY too slow.  Just when it's about to pick up steam, you get bogged down in fetch quests or have to complete a random task that's off the beaten path before proceeding.  After a while, it's simply INFURIATING.

The music, after all these years, still kicks ass though :)
snippet.textOriginal:
My main complaint is that game's plot just moves WAY too slow.  Just when it's about to pick up steam, you get bogged down in fetch quests or have to complete a random task that's off the beaten path before proceeding.  After a while, it's simply INFURIATING.

The music, after all these years, still kicks ass though :)

snippet.textDisplay: Walking speed wasn't that bad to me...the ultra high encounter rate was though.
snippet.textOriginal: Walking speed wasn't that bad to me...the ultra high encounter rate was though.

snippet.textDisplay: Especially with how enormous and maze-like some of the game's dungeons are, the walking speed becomes your worst enemy. Well, that and the lack of save points in dungeons that can take an hour to get through only to die to a boss at the end.
snippet.textOriginal: Especially with how enormous and maze-like some of the game's dungeons are, the walking speed becomes your worst enemy. Well, that and the lack of save points in dungeons that can take an hour to get through only to die to a boss at the end.

snippet.textDisplay: Reminds me the first time I fought against revived Gades, I was like "Holy shit!". I didn't know I was supposed to lose until the battle ended.
snippet.textOriginal: Reminds me the first time I fought against revived Gades, I was like "Holy shit!". I didn't know I was supposed to lose until the battle ended.

snippet.textDisplay: I didn't even know 7.1 was a thing. Every time I think of 5.1 though, I can't not hear that loud, horn-like sound that would always play at the theatre when the Dolby logo popped up before the movie. You'd hear that, and be like, "Shit just got amazing."
snippet.textOriginal: I didn't even know 7.1 was a thing. Every time I think of 5.1 though, I can't not hear that loud, horn-like sound that would always play at the theatre when the Dolby logo popped up before the movie. You'd hear that, and be like, "Shit just got amazing."

snippet.textDisplay: When I had originally watched the final seasons (re-runs?) of MacGyver as a wee lad, I saw that those in charge of the show put up a notification of "In Stereo where available." Now, I pay attention to see if a *video game* supports 5.1 or even 7.1 sound...which was once only a feature of big Hollywood productions 8-^D.
snippet.textOriginal: When I had originally watched the final seasons (re-runs?) of MacGyver as a wee lad, I saw that those in charge of the show put up a notification of "In Stereo where available." Now, I pay attention to see if a *video game* supports 5.1 or even 7.1 sound...which was once only a feature of big Hollywood productions 8-^D.

snippet.textDisplay: When I was young, I used to think it was awesome when a game or movie would be in stereo, and I didn't even know what stereo was. All I knew is that it was better than mono, so I got excited over it.
snippet.textOriginal: When I was young, I used to think it was awesome when a game or movie would be in stereo, and I didn't even know what stereo was. All I knew is that it was better than mono, so I got excited over it.

snippet.textDisplay: "Stereo Sound" used to be a point of pride.
snippet.textOriginal: "Stereo Sound" used to be a point of pride.

snippet.textDisplay: @Christian McNellie"Game Over? What's that?" XP

snippet.textDisplay: @gurvmlk It was because he is very young. Don't take it so hard, you're just getting older. I get it, he probably doesn't know how hard most videogames used to be either.
snippet.textOriginal: @gurvmlk It was because he is very young. Don't take it so hard, you're just getting older. I get it, he probably doesn't know how hard most videogames used to be either.

snippet.textDisplay: @Christian McNellie One night a few years ago, one of my cousin's sons was staying the night. He pointed at my NES on my dresser and asked, "What's that?" Granted it made perfect sense because of his young age (he was only like 6 or 7), it was still one of the hardest to hear questions anybody has ever addressed to me.
snippet.textOriginal: @Christian McNellie One night a few years ago, one of my cousin's sons was staying the night. He pointed at my NES on my dresser and asked, "What's that?" Granted it made perfect sense because of his young age (he was only like 6 or 7), it was still one of the hardest to hear questions anybody has ever addressed to me.

snippet.textDisplay: @gurvmlk I hear what you're saying man! Some of my cousins don't even know what the NES was.
snippet.textOriginal: @gurvmlk I hear what you're saying man! Some of my cousins don't even know what the NES was.

snippet.textDisplay: @Christian McNellie Acceptance for complications far beyond what spoiled kids nowadays with all their functional electronics could ever imagine tolerating.
snippet.textOriginal: @Christian McNellie Acceptance for complications far beyond what spoiled kids nowadays with all their functional electronics could ever imagine tolerating.

snippet.textDisplay: @gurvmlk That's the thing, now you know better methods. What were things like for you about 25 years ago?

snippet.textDisplay: @Christian McNellie I still play my NES to this day, so that's not something I need to try very hard to remember (although nowadays I usually clean them properly since I know better).

snippet.textDisplay: You basically play the prologue.  Most games it would be a cinematic.  But this is one of the first RPGs (that I can think of) which allows you to take control of the character's in the prologue.

snippet.textDisplay: It's similar to the beginning of Tales of Phantasia, except in this case you control the characters.

snippet.textDisplay: sucks that a lot of great rpg games on the snes, were never released here in Europe. =( the only way to play them on a snes is to get an adapter, or to play on emulator.

snippet.textDisplay: It's not put in the clearest way, but it's referring to how at the start of the game, you get to take part in a climactic battle against the Sinistrals, as opposed to having to level grind to even go into the first dungeon. While the game got boring for me soon after the actual game began, that was a nice touch that set it apart from other RPGs.
snippet.textOriginal: It's not put in the clearest way, but it's referring to how at the start of the game, you get to take part in a climactic battle against the Sinistrals, as opposed to having to level grind to even go into the first dungeon. While the game got boring for me soon after the actual game began, that was a nice touch that set it apart from other RPGs.

snippet.textOriginal:
"Battle in the opening story!"

What does this mean???

snippet.textDisplay:
Some thoughts:

This song has 3 strains, 2 of which are the same. So you might say the structure is AAB. Does anyone get the feeling like the song should continue at 1:04 into a 4th strain? (AABC)

Lufia 2's boss battle theme is also divided into 3 strains, ABC. As with Lufia 1's, I get the feeling that it's too short. Seriously, 3 strains? How weird is that? But, Lufia 2's 3rd strain actually resolves, and leads into the 1st strain well. It's also a much more interesting theme than Lufia 1's.
snippet.textOriginal:
Some thoughts:

This song has 3 strains, 2 of which are the same. So you might say the structure is AAB. Does anyone get the feeling like the song should continue at 1:04 into a 4th strain? (AABC)

Lufia 2's boss battle theme is also divided into 3 strains, ABC. As with Lufia 1's, I get the feeling that it's too short. Seriously, 3 strains? How weird is that? But, Lufia 2's 3rd strain actually resolves, and leads into the 1st strain well. It's also a much more interesting theme than Lufia 1's.
